basics.name: Farzad Habibi
basics.label: Ph.D. Student
basics.summary: My name is Farzad Habibi. I'm a fourth-year Ph.D. candidate studying Computer Science at the University of California, Irvine. Previously, I studied a B.Sc. in Computer Engineering at the University of Tehran and worked for 9 month as a full-time software engineer at Radin Bourse where we were developing an ultra-low latency trading platform. My interests are mainly in Distributed Systems and Data Management, and I also love programming. :)

work.name: UC Irvine, Edge Lab
work.summary: Working at UCI Edge Lab under supervision of Prof. Faisal Nawab. We study and build distributed data management systems.We are interested in systems that span large geographic areas and infrastructures, including cloud and edge environments.
highlights: Proposed an optimized distributed concurrency protocol, achieving a 3.8x increase in throughput and a 43% reduction in latency under high-contention workloads.
Proposed a formal analysis and modeling of metastable failures in replicated storage systems using queuing theory, enabling the first-ever modeling of these failures.
Designed a sharding mechanism that improved blockchain resilience by a factor of 6 during global internet outages.
Examined real-world global scale internet partitioning in blockchain architecture to minimize harm and enable rapid recovery.

work.name: Radin Bourse
work.summary: I was part of the team developing a new order-matching engine system for Iran's national stock. This product addresses requirements such as ultra-high performance, low latency (~1μs), scalability, and high availability. Beyond developing new features for the system, I worked on enhancing the response time of distributed event stores deployed within, such as Kafka and Redpanda. We successfully reduced their latency from milliseconds to microseconds.
highlights: Contributed to developing a low-latency ( 1µs) order-matching engine in Java.
Optimized performance of distributed event stores (Kafka, Redpanda) through benchmarking, reducing the order latency from milliseconds to microseconds.
Deployed a containerized monitoring system in the production pipeline using Docker, Prometheus, and Grafana, enabling real-time service monitoring and proactive issue detection.
Deployed a UI for the company’s Ansible codebase using SemaphoreUI, enabling graphical execution of workflows.

work.name: University of Tehran
work.summary: Designed and implemented a virtual network embedding algorithm using Graph Neural Networks (GNN), improving runtime by a factor of 8 and increasing the revenue-to-cost ratio by 18% compared to other simulated algorithms.
work.summary2222: Working on virtual network embedding (VNE) which is a well-known problem in network virtualization. I started to learn about Graph Neural Networks which is a novel machine learning architecture by reading abundance number of related papers. We leveraged this method to solve the VNE problem.

publications.name: Brook-2PL: Tolerating High Contention Workloads with A Deadlock-Free Two-Phase Locking Protocol
publications.publisher: 2026 ACM International Conference on Management of Data (SIGMOD 26)
publications.summary: We introduce Brook-2PL, a new concurrency control protocol that eliminates deadlocks through static analysis and enables early lock release via partial transaction chopping.

publications.name: Deadlocks: A Critical Performance Bottleneck in High-Contention OLTP Systems
publications.publisher: 2025 26th IEEE International Conference on Mobile Data Management (MDM)

publications.name: MSF-Model: Queuing-Based Analysis and Prediction of Metastable Failures in Replicated Storage Systems
publications.publisher: The 43rd International Symposium on Reliable Distributed Systems (SRDS 2024)
publications.summary: Our main contribution is the development of a queuing-based analytical model, MSF-Model, that can be used to characterize and predict metastable failures. MSF-Model integrates novel modeling concepts that allow modeling metastable failures which was interactable to model prior to our work.

publications.name: PeloPartition: Improving Blockchain Resilience to Network Partitioning
publications.summary: we explore the impact of network partitions on blockchain networks and present a sharding protocol to overcome their negative impact.

publications.name: Analyzing soft and hard partitions of global-scale blockchain systems
publications.summary: our goal is to lay the groundwork for the introduction of new blockchain architectures to minimize the harm caused during partitions and facilitate rapid and uncontroversial recovery from them.

publications.name: Accelerating Virtual Network Embedding with Graph Neural Networks
publications.publisher: IEEE/ACM/IFIP Conference on Network and Service Management (CNSM 2020)
publications.summary: virtual network embedding (VNE) is a well-known problem in network virtualization. We leveraged Graph Neural Networks which is a novel machine learning architecture for graphs to solve this problem with a better performance and scalability.
